pr_title: Provide new client and server websocket handshake exceptions

timeline.bodyText: IMHO, I don't think the extra allow*HandshakeException flags are necessary, since both WebSocketClientHandshakeException and WebSocketServerHandshakeException extend WebSocketHandshakeException. I mean, catch (WebSocketHandshakeException e) and e instanceof WebSocketHandshakeException will still work. I hope no one is using e.getClass() == WebSocketHandshakeException.class. I think the extra flags just complicate the code without much benefit.
timeline.author: philsttr
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -144,13 +146,44 @@ protected WebSocketClientHandshaker(URI uri, WebSocketVersion version, String su
     protected WebSocketClientHandshaker(URI uri, WebSocketVersion version, String subprotocol,
                                         HttpHeaders customHeaders, int maxFramePayloadLength,
                                         long forceCloseTimeoutMillis, boolean absoluteUpgradeUrl) {
+        this(uri, version, subprotocol, customHeaders, maxFramePayloadLength, forceCloseTimeoutMillis,
+             false, false);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Base constructor
+     *
+     * @param uri
+     *            URL for web socket communications. e.g "ws://myhost.com/mypath". Subsequent web socket frames will be
+     *            sent to this URL.
+     * @param version
+     *            Version of web socket specification to use to connect to the server
+     * @param subprotocol
+     *            Sub protocol request sent to the server.
+     * @param customHeaders
+     *            Map of custom headers to add to the client request
+     * @param maxFramePayloadLength
+     *            Maximum length of a frame's payload
+     * @param forceCloseTimeoutMillis
+     *            Close the connection if it was not closed by the server after timeout specified
+     * @param  absoluteUpgradeUrl
+     *            Use an absolute url for the Upgrade request, typically when connecting through an HTTP proxy over
+     *            clear HTTP
+     * @param  allowClientHandshakeException
+     *             Whether to return a basic {@link WebSocketHandshakeException}
+     *             or client {@link WebSocketClientHandshakeException} that contains a http response

replies.bodyText: I totally agree about code complication and most likely it not bring a benefit. I hope we can remove it to keep code simple if no one is against.
replies.author: amizurov

replies.bodyText: I agree, people should not rely on the concrete exception type such that we cannot throw a sub-class instead.
replies.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: You forgot to include the field value here.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.message: Provide new client and server websocket handshake exceptions for handling upgrade issues
Provide new client and server websocket handshake exceptions for handling upgrade issues

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if it would be better to expose the protocol, status and headers directly here. This would make it clear that this HttpResponse is never a FullHttpResponse and so not needs to be released. WDYT ?
timeline.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: I thought about this, but we have situations when an exception occurs before receiving a response and we do not have this data and all fields will be null, which is inconvenient (need to check before use) or we can throw the different type of exceptions with response data and  without it.
replies.author: amizurov

replies.bodyText: got it... maybe we should just add to the java docs that this will never be ReferenceCounted and so no special treatment is needed.
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Make sense, even that WebSocket Handshake request/response in theory should not contain payload, but this is not explicitly prohibited by the RFC 😲
replies.author: amizurov

timeline.bodyText:
let's make the constructors package-private and add:
assert !(httpRequest instanceof ReferenceCounted);
timeline.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Hmm what kind of benefit for package-private constructors?, maybe user want to create it own exception Server or Client exception and handle it in common manner.
replies.author: amizurov

replies.bodyText: I was thinking of make it more safe in terms of not pass in ReferenceCounted objects. That said as you mention before we copy it anyway so not a big deal
replies.author: normanmaurer

timeline.bodyText: assert !(httpRequest instanceof ReferenceCounted); and make constructors package private for now
timeline.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Hmm, we create our own DefaultHttpResponse in constructor, we don't set given response directly.
replies.author: amizurov
